intro: Commiphora coleopsis, commonly known as the African myrrh, is a small evergreen tree or shrub native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing species. The plant is characterized by its smooth, grayish bark and opposite, oval-shaped leaves. It produces small, yellowish flowers and is known for its aromatic resin, which has been used traditionally in incense and medicinal applications. The plant thrives in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates.
